Award.AwardTitle: Period domains and related studies in arithmetic
Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposer K. Kato constructed moduli spaces of degenerating mixed Hodge structures in joint works with C. Nakayama and S. Usui. This extends the classical theory of toroidal compactifications of Hermitian symmetric domains. He also obtained the p-adic analogue of it. These works on period domains are related to many interesting areas. Asymptotic behaviors of regulator maps and local height pairings, degeneration of motives, asymptotic behaviors of divergences which occur in physics, Hodge conjecture, and also to Iwasawa theory. The relation to Iwasawa theory comes from the fact that the regulator maps and zeta values are related, and also comes from the fact that the boundary of the compactifications of modular varieties play important roles in the generalization of Sharifi conjectures which give refinements of Iwasawa main conjecture. The study of degeneration is also related to ramification theory of schemes. The proposer wishes to study these areas. In the generalization of Sharifi conjectures, he collaborates with the co-principal investigator T. Fukaya.

This study provides new interactions between Hodge theory, arithmeticand physics. People in different areas can enter the other fields via this study. The proposer anticipates that many graduate students will choose to write theses in areas related to the materials in this proposal.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Heights of numbers expresses the complexity of numbers. They are important in number theory. It is generalized to heights of points of algebraic varieties over number fields, and this theory played important roles in arithmetic geometry, for example, in the proof of Mordell-Weil theorem and in the proof of Mordell conjecture by Faltings. In this project, K. Kato created the theory of heights of motives. Basing on the work of K. Kato, Koshikawa proved that the famous Tate conjecture for algebraic cycles is true if the number of motives of bounded heights is finite. This theory of heights of motives seems to become important in the future of arithmetic geometry.

Nevanlinna theory studies how often meromorphic functions on the complex plane have given special values. The analogy between Navanlinna theory and the theory of heights of numbers was studied by Vojta and other people. K. Kato started a new Nevanlinna theory, the Hodge-Nevanlinna theory which studies how often variations of Hodge structures on a complex plane degenerate, and found the analogy between this new Nevanlinna theory and the theory of heights of motives. This is a new field of study which provides many interesting problems.


This theory of heights of motives is closely related to the theory of extended period domains studied by K. Kato, C. Nakayama and S. Usui obtained in this project. Important theorems on asymptotic behaviors of heights of motives can be deduced from the study of degeneration of Hodge structures studied by K. Kato, S. Usui and C. Nakayama obtained in this project.

Iwasawa main conjecture states a connection between algebraic objects (ideal class groups etc.) and analytic objects (zeta functions, p-adic zeta functions etc.). R. Sharifi formulated a refined version of Iwasawa main conjecture concerning the relation of modular symbols and ideal class groups. In this project, T. Fukaya, K. Kato and R. Sharifi generalized the conjectures of Sharifi to the relation of the modular symbols for GL(n) and the Iwasawa theory of GL(n-1). T. Fukaya and K. Kato have strong results in the case n=2, and T. Fukaya, K. Kato and R. Sharifi obtained strong results in the geometric analogue of the case n=2 in this project. To generalized the last results to the case n > 2, in this project, T. Fukaya, K. Kato and R. Sharifi established the theory of compactifications of S-arithmetic quotients of the Bruhat-Tits buildings and its analogues for number fields, and then established the theory of toroidal compactifications of the moduli spaces of Drinfeld modules. The ideals of these theory of compactifications base on the theory of extended period domains of K. Kato, C. Nakayama, and S. Usui obtained in this project, and also on the theory of log abelian varieties of T. Kajiwara, K. Kato and C. Nakayama obtained in this project,

By the study in this project, analytic theory (Nevanlinna theory, Hodge theory, curvature forms on Griffiths domains), and number theory are connected by new methods.
